page.lettertext:
fol.6r
Honnorable S
r
,
wee her
majesties
fore Captain[es]
yeat faythfull, and most loyall in o[ur]
place, wheare wee are Imployed, doe sa[.]
unto your Lor. w
th
these, most humblye
beseachinge you to taske suche notes
of a petition, the w
ch
wee have writte[n]
to the
Stat
,
as you in your wisdom
shall finde best beseaming our honno[r]
and the Repeutation of our Nation.
Wee macke noe question, but that the
same shall cum unto your readinge, &
theirfore will [mee], but brieflye to ad[.]
unto you, the Content
theirof.
wee are by sum divellishe & moste
ungodlye persons, Charged to have
Intellygence, and to goe about to
betraye this towne unto the Enemy
yf the same maye not be prove[n]
wee knowe yt can not, then doe
earnestlye beseache you soe to
prosecute our accusors, as that
theire maye be the lycke punnish[ment]
Inflicted upon them, as should have
bein fitt for us, yf the same coul[d]
have bein founde trewe. The grea[t]
Charge from our Lord Governor,
together w
th
the assewered confyden[ce]
wee have that the Stat
will
dewlye consyder what wee are, &
the nateuer of the accusation
dothe & hathe w
th
helde some of
fol.6v
from satisfinge our selfes [.]
bloudd of them & soe the s[.]
shall still cause us to pawse [.]
understand what will be d[.]
by them theire. and soe, as we[.]
Refer our selfes to your honno[rable]
care of us hearin, soe doe wee
beseache your Lordship to adv[.]
the delyverye of the sayed [.]
by the meanes of this [berer.]
your Lord shall finde us ever [.]
redie to doe you all the service [.]
wee can & soe moste humblye
tacke our leaves from Ostend
5 Janeuarie. 1595.
Yo
r
Lor. moste liu[.]
to Commaunde.
[Prob gachim]
Charles Brest
Thomas Farances
J Heochmacke
George Aldryche
Water F[.]
Richard Su[.]
